title: Greek Tutor

loading.title: Preparing Your Study Session
loading.subtitle: Analyzing the biblical passage with advanced exegetical tools
loading.footer: Faithful study of Scripture honors God and edifies His people
tips: Greek word order is flexible thanks to its case system
Greek verb tenses communicate aspect more than chronological time
Pay attention to prepositions, as they often carry deep theological nuances
The definite article in Greek functions differently than in English
Participles are verbal adjectives that share characteristics of both

description: The ecosystem of tools for biblical study and sermon preparation.

passageSelector.label: Biblical Passage
passageSelector.invalidReferenceDesc: Please enter a valid biblical reference (e.g., John 3:16).

readPassage.title: Read Passage
readPassage.description: Explore the biblical text in its original language with interactive tools to deepen your understanding.
details: View original Greek text with Spanish version options
Click any Greek word to add to study units

syntax.title: Syntactic Structure
syntax.description: Visualize grammatical relationships and clause hierarchy in the Greek text.
details: Hierarchical view of main and subordinate clauses
Understand the author's logical argument structure

morphology.title: Morphological Analysis
morphology.description: Detailed breakdown of each word into its basic morphological components.
details: Visual separation of roots, prefixes, and suffixes
Identification of tense, voice, mood, case, and number
Connection between form and grammatical function
Deepen understanding of Greek word construction

recognitionKeys.title: Recognition Keys
recognitionKeys.description: Morphological patterns helping you identify grammatical forms quickly.
details: Examples of each pattern in context
Develop reading skills without a dictionary

contextFunction.title: Function in Context
contextFunction.description: Understand the role each word plays within its clause and the full passage.
details: Identification of syntactic role (subject, object, modifier)
Relationship with other words in the clause
Connection to the passage's general argument

expertInsight.title: Expert Insight
expertInsight.description: Deep perspectives from grammarians and exegetes on text meaning and implications.
details: Expert explanations of author's grammatical choices
Transforms grammatical knowledge into theological understanding

generalConcepts.title: General Concepts
generalConcepts.description: Reference library of fundamental Koine Greek concepts.
details: Guide to verb tenses and meanings

tutorQuestions.title: Ask Tutor
tutorQuestions.description: Ask personalized questions about any aspect of the text and receive contextualized answers.
tutorQuestions.preview: How does this verb function here?
details: Ask about grammar, syntax, or theology
Answers based on specific passage context
Learn at your own pace with expert guidance

quiz.title: Comprehension Quiz
quiz.description: Evaluate and reinforce your Greek understanding with interactive exercises.
details: Multiple choice questions on morphology and syntax
Exercises based on the study passage

myInsights.title: My Insights
myInsights.description: View and manage your saved personal notes and insights.

onboarding.intro: This tool helps you understand the Greek text structure before studying individual words.
onboarding.steps: I'll show you the key elements in 5 quick steps.
onboarding.skipTip: üí° You can skip this tutorial at any time
onboarding.step1Content: Read this blue box first. It gives you the full picture of the passage's argument.
onboarding.step2Content1: Clauses with blue background are the main ones - the backbone of the text.
onboarding.step2Content2: Identify the main verb (position indicated below) and the subject.
onboarding.step3Content1: Indented clauses depend on the main one.
onboarding.step3Content2: The color tells you its function: green (purpose), orange (cause), etc.
onboarding.step3Question: Question: "How does this clause modify the main one?"
onboarding.step4Content: Use these buttons to control what you see:
onboarding.step4Collapse: Collapse All: Only main clauses (for overview)
onboarding.step4Tip: üí° Start collapsed to avoid being overwhelmed
onboarding.step5Content1: Each color represents a clause type with a specific function.
onboarding.step5Content2: For example: Green = Purpose ("so that..."), Orange = Cause ("because...")
onboarding.step5Done: ‚úÖ Ready! Now you know how to use syntactic analysis.

quiz.testPrompt: Test what you have learned about

morphology.analysisTitle: Analysis of the components that form this Greek word
morphology.tipContent: Observe how the prefix changes the nuances of the root verb.

concepts.selectActionPrompt: Select an action from the side panel to start your study
